title: Susan B. Anthony Papers: Daybook and Diaries, 1856-1906; Diaries; 1903

entries.fullText:
I had in Bank as follows

Fidelity Trust C. 1137.08
Washington Savings Bank 238.90
Rochester " " 155.44
Monroe County " 3,026.70
Security Trust 2,605.20
__________
$7,163.32


January
Thur
1

This day ushers in the year
1903 - it is very pleasantly warm though
thawing - Sister Mary & self are alone
save the girl - Nettie Booth - who got
us a chicken dinner - and then took
the remainder to a poor woman rich
unto death - with six children. Mrs
Greenleaf called - Have 5 orders for Life and Word
bound in Morocco - I havent that number -
I had them - sent to Miss Eddy - + Mrs Rankin
had two sets - & sent them to Miss Eliz. [?] I. Eaton -
so they are all gone -
I sat this eve and thought of brother
[?]on as the only other member of our family -
would that I could slip in & chat with him --
entries.summaryText: Bank account balance and a journal entry about the first day of the year.

entries.fullText:
Both of us went to Church
heard Mr Gamrett on "now" - it was good
Mrs Gamrett insisted we should both go home
with her to dinner - so we consented - she stopped
into a drug store & telephoned - so Leticia knew
more was com'g - Had a good deal of talk of
Sister Mary's refusing to pay her $2,000 over to the
Movement - unless the powers that be will give a
guarantee that the pledge of perfect equality
shall be kept - - Had a beautiful dinner of
Roast beef, splendid joint, peas & potatos - if
had stopped there all would have been splendid - but
I took a small piece of mince pie, cheese - & a cup of coffee -
and the dickens to pay - We went with
Mr Gamrett to Young Peoples meeting at 4.P.M.
I told them of Samuel Longfellow but to my amazement,
I couldn't find that he spoke on [?] in her
Con. of 1860 = he must have said it to me in
private - but alas every one who was there is dead now - Mrs
Stanton herself was the last one - being I am left alone
of all the older ones -

I took a small piece of Mince
pie and it has played the Dickens with me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends church, has dinner with the Gamretts, and discusses Sister Mary's refusal to pay $2,000 to the Movement unless a guarantee of perfect equality is made. She also attends a Young Peoples meeting and suffers from eating mince pie.

entries.fullText:
feeling pretty badly - but
Mrs Calgrove came, I dictated
some letters - I had the Dr Ricker
yesterday P.M. He gave me medicine-
something for my heart which acts
all the time as if I had been running
to the top of my speed - it has been
coming on for three months or more
-it is very annoying in the nights
- I can't lay on my left side with
any comfort - indeed I hear the beating
awake or asleep -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony feels unwell and receives a visit from Mrs. Calgrove. She also receives medicine from Dr. Ricker for her heart condition.

entries.fullText:
A long letter from Mrs. Harper
gave many particulars of her life in
Washington - She told of her talk with
Mr Stafford about my books - the old ones.
- I felt better but not right
yet - it is strange what honor one
little piece of mince pie can play.
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Harper wrote a letter about her life in Washington and her talk with Mr. Stafford about Susan's books.

entries.fullText:
Received a paper from Pennsylvania
contains the notice of the death of ("Bill
Davis") William H. Davis. his daughter
married - Mr. Charles H. Whitaker - Toledo, Ohio
I remember his mother Olive Stafford
Janis very well - she was a sister of Aunt
Mary Stafford Read - Uncle Joshua's wife -
Davis was born in Oct, 25, 1824 -- so he was
two months younger than brother Dan - he
was buried at Palatine Bridge - Olive married
N Whitaker - and Edith aline married Mr.
Wm S. Hawks of the Manhattan Hotel - New York
entries.summaryText: Susan received a newspaper from Pennsylvania with the notice of Bill Davis' death and some information about his family and relatives.

entries.fullText: at home and at work on the old books & papers
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home and worked on old books and papers on January 8th, 1903.

entries.fullText: at home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony was at home on January 9th, 1903.

entries.fullText:
Opened by mistake + got
half through before discovering - a
letter from May Wright Sewall - to
Mrs. Barber - It was about the
reason that she had abdicated her
post - as Pres. of the International Council.
I had heard of it but knew it was a
mistake - - Get no books yet
from the Hollenbecks - the people
are impatient enough - I do not wonder.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a letter from May Wright Sewall about her abdication as President of the International Council.

entries.fullText:
Snowing all day -
I remained at home - Sister Mary
went to Church, new ideas of Christ -
made feel to wish I had gone - Rev
Gannett always gives me food for thought -
Got two letters asking for help for
Clubs - one from Anna Pillsbury-Young --
Manhattan, Kansas - asking a word on
Kansas - re-submission or anything - the
other from Columbus Ohio - I have
enough such requests to keep me busy -
were to devote the time necessary.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received two letters asking for help for clubs, one from Anna Pillsbury-Young in Manhattan, Kansas and the other from Columbus, Ohio.

entries.fullText:
Looking over old papers
Wrote letter to Mrs Anne Pillsbury
Young -- Manhattan -- Kansas, to be
read at their club -- Mrs Young is
daughter of Mr Pillsbury -- who
was a cousin of Parker Pillsbury -- and
a pioneer in Kansas --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about looking over old papers and writing a letter to Mrs. Anne Pillsbury. She mentions a Mrs. Young from Manhattan, Kansas who is the daughter of Mr. Pillsbury and a cousin of Parker Pillsbury, who was a pioneer in Kansas.

entries.fullText:
Wrote in the Anti Slavery
Standard's -- & Liberators - But
They were secured at of the old
Papers of - Elias & Rhoda De Garmo -- Isaac
& Amy Post -- William & Mary Hallowell - Daniel &
Lucy Anthony -- read by all four families -
religiously -- and by their neighbors, friends --
the Standards are from 1852 - to 1865 -- and
the Liberators from 1843 to 1865 --
Wrote letters to Nebraska women --
Laura Gregg- to the [deaf and dumb] no
Blind children -- Mrs Kendrick -- and
to New York home -- for my birth
day - Feb. 15, 1903 when I shall be 83 --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about reading old papers from the Anti Slavery Standard and Liberators, and writing letters to women in Nebraska, Laura Gregg, Mrs. Kendrick, and to her New York home in preparation for her upcoming 83rd birthday on February 15, 1903.

entries.fullText: Miss Margaret Haley of Chicago -- arrived at 10 A.M. -- she is to lecture this evening on Chicago Tax Payers -- she is young, bright woman -- who says she never knows what it is to feel tired. Mrs. Montgomery to call at 3. o clock - 5 -- Teachers invited to Miss Nicholson, Mrs. Clemence Houseman, Miss Mary Sterling, Miss Connell, Miss Frank Beichenbach -- here to supper -- a very lively talk -- each one seemed not able to wait for the other -- The Teachers sent a carriage & Miss Sterling, Miss Housman with Miss Haley rode on to the Unitarian Church -- It was filled, a good many teachers came. Miss Haley's talk was fine-- she showed how the teachers -- 3.500 -- make of themselves a force -- there are nearly 6.000 teachers in Chicago. We went to Depot with her -- she had to be in Chicago to a meeting of Teachers Federation at 10:30 -- The limited that leaves at 10:15 gets there at 10 --
entries.summaryText: Margaret Haley arrived to lecture on Chicago Tax Payers. Teachers were invited to dinner and lively conversation. Haley's talk was well received and she showed how teachers can make themselves a force.

entries.fullText: Dictated 9 letters - Mr. E. J. Chapin sent $28 - the last payment of Mr. & Mrs Bruce - colored - my property in Fort Scott will soon be all sold out - I wish Sister Mary's were as nearly sold - Mary went to Educational, Industrial Union it was book-day - very interesting - I took a short sleep - meantime - wrote Anna Shaw at Minneapolis - and Ivy E. of Phila - got a letter from Mrs. Catt - they are getting started finally - it but a week since they set foot in [C?] - March 10th makes a very short campaign -
entries.summaryText: Anthony dictated letters and received a payment. Her property in Fort Scott is almost sold out. Mary attended an interesting book-day event at the Educational, Industrial Union. Anthony corresponded with Anna Shaw, Ivy E., and received a letter from Mrs. Catt about their campaign starting soon.

entries.fullText:
Went to Church - cold & blustery -
and snowy - Mrs Gannett talked to
Mary & me about - her $2000: to her
university - so after we got home
she wrote a form of letter to Mrs Eastwood
- She received a letter from Mr Rufus A. Libby -
saying they had no authority to accept any
money on her conditions - and she then named
none but those in the pledge book -
The men do seem afraid to say the truth -
they want the money - but don't want to say
their college will be kept free & equal to women -
got letter from Mrs Catt - New Hampshire
She is getting things started well -
A fire in the Bindery
department of Hollenbecks Press - destroyed
the Covers & part of the sheets - So
that they have to print part of the
sheets & make all the covers - it does
seem as if the fates were against us -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Gannett talked about her university donation, received a letter from Mr Rufus A. Libby, and a fire destroyed part of the sheets at Hollenbecks Press.

entries.fullText:
at home -
writing in the woman's journal books -
and the Woman's Tribune home Volumes -
to send to the Congressional Library -
A letter from Anna H Shaw - she is in
Iowa - lost her first lecture - 50 dollars
because of slow train -
Mrs. Wentworth called - of Chicago -
She expressed a good deal of gratitude
that my work had opened the way for her - &c -
she brought some lilies of the valley - and
some sweet scented violets - very nice -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote in journals and received a letter from Anna H Shaw. Mrs. Wentworth visited and expressed gratitude.

entries.dateText:
January
Sat
24

I got a letter this day from Hollenbeck Press--saying they had a fire the 18th that destroyed all their covers and part of the sheets--to Vol. IV. So my work was delayed two weeks--in getting them ready -- I wrote them a "hurry up" letter last night.
entries.fullText: I got a letter this day from Hollenbeck Press--saying they had a fire the 18th that destroyed all their covers and part of the sheets--to Vol. IV. So my work was delayed two weeks--in getting them ready -- I wrote them a "hurry up" letter last night.
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Hollenbeck Press about a fire that delayed her work for two weeks.

entries.dateText:
January
Sun
25

Did not go to Church -- Mary did - and saw that Mrs. Gannett was quite ill - almost fainted before going to the Chapel -
entries.fullText: Did not go to Church -- Mary did - and saw that Mrs. Gannett was quite ill - almost fainted before going to the Chapel -
entries.summaryText: Mary went to church and saw that Mrs. Gannett was quite ill.

entries.fullText: Mrs (Doctor) Martin- and Mrs Hannah B. Clark were here to tea - & spent evening- Maria Wilder Duprey - called & made quite a visit - Mrs Fenner called in the evening She has 25 lbs of English Walnuts for me - 20 a lb- - Just $5.- They are fresh - from Dr Adams Ranch at Orange - California - he had money enough to hold on to his farm- So he is making money off it now - But poor Geo. Baker - lost all he had - and went back to the R.R. business again -
entries.summaryText: Mrs (Doctor) Martin, Mrs Hannah B. Clark, Maria Wilder Duprey, Mrs Fenner, Dr Adams, and Geo. Baker were mentioned. Mrs Fenner brought 25 lbs of English Walnuts from Dr Adams Ranch in Orange, California.

entries.fullText: I wrote to Miss Bessie M. Bass - Waterloo - Iowa - She is to act for me - she has written a very good speech - an afternoon with Cranks - they call it Rosevelt - Miss Shaw - Mrs Addams &c This my dear father's 109 - birth day - how time does fly - I can see him looking young & fresh - as he did the year this [?]
entries.summaryText: Miss Bessie M. Bass, Miss Shaw, and Mrs Addams were mentioned. Susan B. Anthony wrote to Miss Bass and it was her father's 109th birthday.

entries.fullText:
This was the annual
meeting of the Local Council -
Mrs A.A. Armstrong was elected
President - Mrs Rosenthal has
made a good one - if she only
was in good health - she would
have continued. - Mrs. Armstrong
is very hopeful of getting a bill
through the Legislature - giving women
the right to vote for School Commission -
but it is going through with a great
deal of work for so small a
thing - just over in two years
vote for school commission - but
keep up the agitation.
entries.summaryText: Annual meeting of the Local Council, Mrs A.A. Armstrong elected President, discussion of bill to give women the right to vote for School Commission.

entries.fullText:
Working at the old [?]
books - alone - stenographer
not here at all - this week-
Got a letter from R. Burt
Anthony saying his mother
lives with him - they were living
in two rooms - and he was
living on things she cooked and
he felt a great deal better
for it -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about working alone and receiving a letter from R. Burt Anthony about his living situation with his mother.

entries.fullText:
This is Sister Guelma's
husband - Aaron M Mc Lean's
90th birth - he was born Jan 31,.1819 -
Sister Guelma would have been 84 - Their
only daughter that lives - is Maggie -
and she has three sons & one daughter -
the last I heard of them she & Guelma
were in Chicago -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the 90th birthday of Aaron M Mc Lean, Sister Guelma's husband, and mentions their daughter Maggie and her family living in Chicago.

entries.fullText:
Warm - soft - day
Went to Church with Sister
Mary - The sermon was the
Kindergarten way of teaching religion
- he showed how Christ taught
by parables - not by stating
directly the principles - they
were most successful preachers
who could picture - a word
hasnt - Every thing - he mentions
Moody - & Talmadge - as
wonderful picture makers - story
tellers \ Miss Shaw starts for
New Hampshire to day - she goes for
just two weeks - I do hope they will
carry the vote - it would be so good
to claim an Easter vote!
entries.summaryText: Attended church with Sister Mary and heard a sermon on the Kindergarten way of teaching religion. Mentions Moody, Talmadge, and Miss Shaw leaving for New Hampshire.

entries.fullText: Mrs. May Storking Knaggs of Bay City, Michigan - will reach here on the 9. train - this day --
entries.summaryText: Mrs. May Storking Knaggs of Bay City, Michigan is arriving on the 9th train.

entries.fullText:
Mrs May Stocking Knaggs - of
Bay City, Michigan, came to dinner
to - not jesting- she was on her way to
her mother - 82. years old - at Spring Valley
in Cayuga Co - she left on the 2.30 train - and
had to ride in stage from Port Byron - 8 miles
- a pretty cold ride -
entries.summaryText: Mrs May Stocking Knaggs visits Susan B. Anthony on her way to visit her 82-year-old mother in Spring Valley, Cayuga Co.

entries.fullText:
To-day got off to Washington
DC. - to the library of Congress
four (4) boxes of books, anti Slavery
Standard, the Liberator, the Revolution - the
ballot box & National Citizen, Woman's Tribune, the
Woman's Journal - and various sets of Convention
Reports - before & after the way - and
one volume of bound tracts - It was a
great relief to get all shipped - I shall
have a few - like Vol. IV - and the set of
the History - yet to send -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony ships boxes of books to the library of Congress in Washington DC.

entries.fullText:
Weather colder & wind
blowing - letters from the seat
of War - giving little that is hopeful
about a victory in New Hampshire
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the weather and receiving letters from the seat of War, which give little hope about a victory in New Hampshire.

entries.fullText:
This day sister Mary and
self went to dinner at Sarah L
Willis - Jacob Post & two daughters
were there - we had Roast Turkey
and a splendid dinner - we came
home early - Mrs Willis sent her
man to take us over & back -
- all very nice -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about having dinner with her sister Mary at Sarah L Willis' house, where they had roast turkey and a splendid dinner. Mrs Willis sent her man to take them over and back.

entries.fullText:
To day began the appearance
of iching on my back --
seems very quiet -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the appearance of itching on her back.

entries.fullText:
My back so bad
that I called the Doctor -
Marcena Sherman Ricker - She
seemed to think it came from
exhaustion - over work - and
failure of the foods assimilating -
She left medicine -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about calling the doctor, Marcena Sherman Ricker, for her back pain and the doctor's diagnosis of exhaustion and failure of food assimilation.

entries.fullText:
Had the doctor in
these days - but kept
up -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a doctor visit on February 11th.

entries.fullText:
Had the doctor in
these days -- but kept
up --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a doctor's visit but kept up.

entries.fullText:
Anna Davis Mrs
Gilbert came to
supper - -They are
good & true --
[?] [?]
time for [?] [?]
A different [?]
letters + books
entries.summaryText: Anna Davis and Mrs Gilbert came to supper. Susan B. Anthony mentions receiving letters and books.

entries.fullText:
This is my 83rd birth Day --
a nurse came this night -- my
back is getting worse instead of
better -- Nettie Booth - the kitchen girl
will not sleep here - & I was not
willing to stay in the house with Sister
Mary the only well person -- and she almost
76 -- So resorted to a nurse --
I did not go to Church -- in
the evening -- Mary & I called on Mrs
Eliza Woodbury Woodward -- whose husband
John Woodward died a few days ago -- She
is left with two daughters - and has a
brother who will live with her -- and is
left with money enough to live on --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her 83rd birthday, a nurse coming to take care of her, and visiting Mrs. Eliza Woodbury Woodward.

entries.fullText:
I came down to the
reception in the P M. and 90.
people called -- took a sleep
between times -- & came down at
8 & staid until after 10 -- there
was quite a hundred in the evening -
but the storm was fearful --
Anna H. Shaw came to breakfast --
from New Hampshire - and received
with me -- I was glad enough to see
her -- & have her with us -- we had
little pictures of Miss Shaw & me tied
with yellow ribbon -- as we had on Mrs
Stanton's birth day -- Mrs Stanton & me tied with
yellow ribbon -- it seems so strange to link
any other name with mine than Mrs Stantons --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a reception with 90 people, a storm, and having breakfast with Anna H. Shaw.

entries.fullText:
My back was fearful
this day -- after dinner
the nurse rubbed it with [?ine?]
and a little carbolic acid in it -- &
nearly drove me frantic --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her painful back and the nurse's treatment.

entries.fullText:
I told Dr Ricker I
had been thinking of sending
for Dr [Gob?] -- old school -- to see
if he couldn't stop the terrible
itching on back -- and nearly
all over me -- He laughed --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony discusses her plan to seek treatment for her itching with Dr. Ricker, who laughed at her suggestion.

entries.fullText:
all these days
growing worse - the
night was something dreadful
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about feeling worse and having a dreadful night.

entries.fullText:
I came down to Mrs
Burns -- of Livonia's --.
musical reception -- some
50 -- here -- she is a colored woman
living at Livonia -- [?] Co. -- &
has many pupils - white as well as
colored -- says she knows nothing of
prejudice against color -- she is the only
woman in the village -- as is taken into the
Church & all society -- Livonia is a
bright spot -- She gave the children &
young people a souvenir -- & lemonade &
cake -- They went away very happy --
entries.summaryText: Attended a musical reception at Mrs. Burns' in Livonia where she has many pupils, both white and colored, and is accepted into the church and society.

entries.fullText: No church for me
entries.summaryText: Did not attend church.

entries.fullText:
I received Hollenbecks letter, saying
they had shipped 21 boxes
of books - 250 - in all - good
news -
entries.summaryText: Received letter from Hollenbecks about shipment of 21 boxes of books.

entries.fullText: March Thur 5

We had 21 come this
afternoon - 21 boxes - it did
seem good - to feel they were
actually here -

on tour
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had 21 visitors and 21 boxes arrived while on tour.

entries.fullText:
sent by express to
Editors-38
Contributors 55-of Chapters
Libraries 41-
Friends-5-Total 139
Put Up - & put in a good days work -
wrote in the 55 Vol. IV - who were the
contributors of the History Chapters - and
the five for friends - making 60 - in all

old fashioned way of ballotting - so
that we shall not know the facts
of the Election - 80,000 men are to
vote upon the question whether women
should have the right to vote -
Mr O.S. Stevens called with a dozzen
eggs - I gave him a [?] copy of
Vol IV - he and his sisters Elizabeth and
Ellen A. Stevens - live together - & are by
[?] -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about sending books to editors, contributors, libraries, and friends. She also wrote about Mr. O.S. Stevens visiting her with his sisters.

entries.fullText:
sent to [Dral??s] . 29 orders
contributors to [Hindri?] fund 32
Individual orders-34
Total sent 95
Miss G. L. Hawkin almost died this day}
Wrote in the 32 - contributors
to the Standing Fund - in 1900 - saying
This huge volume IV- I present to you in
recognition of your contributing [?] [?] -
to the standing fund for H. of W.S - and
your cheerful consent for this
transference of the money to the
printing of this book -- Hoping that
the sett - four volumes - may be placed
in all the libraries of the country - where
every student of history may have access
to it" --These have been two full days
work -- I got word that then 4. other
boxes are here -There are 250 - books
in the first four boxes - and 10 sent to
Mrs Harper and me - make 260 - in all -
The fate of New Hampshire
is decided ere this - but they have the
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about sending orders and books to contributors and almost losing Miss G. L. Hawkin. She also wrote about hoping that the books will be placed in all the libraries of the country.

entries.fullText:
Writing in books all day - but
many interruptions - wrote that I
sent &c because of their being Life
Member - and because I wanted to enlist
them in getting the book into libraries - Colleges
High Schools - Normal Schools &c - where every student
could learn the facts about women during the
19th Century - facts that could not be obtained from
any other source" -
Mrs. Greenleaf called
this P.M. - and Dr. & Mrs. Lanford
called in the evening -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about writing in books all day and sending books to Life Members. She also mentions Mrs. Greenleaf and Dr. & Mrs. Lanford visiting her.

entries.fullText:
Sent off to Life Members
37- vol. IV - to Life Members
of the National Woman S. Association
to Thomas Mott Osborne . Auburn, N.Y.
a copy directed to "The Mayor" -
Anna [D???] Mason came & sewed
for Sister Mary all day - and washed sister Mary's
head & cut her corns - Gilbert came to supper
- they are very good & true -
Mrs. Colegrove not here to day -
Mamie home - had a dozzen eggs -
to me - fresh laid - very nice of her -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about sending books to Life Members and mentions various people who visited her, including Anna [D???] Mason, Gilbert, Mrs. Colegrove, and Mamie.

entries.fullText:
Worked like a trojan all day-
Anna D. Iram fix dresses - ruchings &c - all day
for me - at night Gilbert came again to help get us
up even - we took 7.52 evening train - Anna Steven & son
the house alone - after we were gone - Nettie Booth -
wanted full pay for the times we were gone - though she
refused two [?] [?] that wanted help - [?] told
her hence one thing I had not thought of - that we may
have a [?] to sleep at our house nights -
that settled it with her - she must go and sleep
at Mrs. Coopers - she wasn't well & needed her -
I [?] Mrs. [Galegone?] paying her off-
So said good bye to both
of these women-
We took sleeper
Dr. Marcus Thomas Recker
Lydia Reicher Webber - sister
Mary & self - made the [?] -
then Dr called - with her husband to
take us to the station --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day, including issues with a worker and her departure on a train.

entries.fullText:
arrived at Washington
at 7. A.M. - went to the
Riggs - it will seem the most
like home -- went up to the
Congressional Library - saw
Mr. Spofford - he has a plate
made for my books - thinks there
are none too many of them -
Mrs Harper called for me - and we
drove all around & up to the Capitol
- she went into library with me - she
had Mrs. Henderson's horses & carriage
and called at Mrs. Barkers -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Washington and visits the Congressional Library with Mrs. Harper.

entries.fullText:
March
Sun
15

Took Southern R.R. at
11 A.M. and went to New
Orleans -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took the Southern R.R. to New Orleans.

entries.fullText:
We reached New Orleans at
9 P.M. - and went to [?][?]
Charles - Mrs. Gordon was present
to [?] us to Hotel - and Mrs.
Frank Goshen's carriage was on hand -
Sta. Cody gives carriage to go to &
from Hotel during the Convention
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in New Orleans and was greeted by Charles, Mrs. Gordon, and Mrs. Frank Goshen. Sta. Cody provided a carriage for transportation during the Convention.

entries.fullText:
Executive meeting this [?]
& Thursday [?]
entries.summaryText: There was an executive meeting on Wednesday and Thursday.

entries.fullText:
Business meeting in this
P.M. and all went to
reception to Mrs. [Josephine]
Reuben Bush - 1205 Josephine St.
and in evening was the opening
meeting - with a good audience
entries.summaryText: Attended a business meeting and a reception at Mrs. Reuben Bush's house. Later attended the opening meeting with a good audience.

entries.fullText:
We went to the Gordons -
The mother, three
daughters Katie &
to a reception -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to a reception with the Gordons, including Katie and her mother and sisters.

entries.fullText:
arrived home at 9 p.m. -
no girl - looks dark
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived home at 9 p.m. and noted that there was no girl and it looked dark.

entries.fullText:
This P.M. at 4 Oclock - I have
promised to speak to the
Mother's Club - of No 4 Public
School-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has promised to speak to the Mother's Club of No 4 Public School.

entries.fullText:
I carried
Mr & Mrs Gannet
Vol III, Leather &
Sunday morning the 10th
carried Vol. II for the
Sunday School library
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony carried Mr & Mrs Gannet's Vol III, Leather & on May 8th and carried Vol. II for the Sunday School library on May 10th.

entries.fullText:
Came home from Arma
Derm Masons - after nearly three
weeks of banishment on account
of Paint - Received seven
Boxes of books from Hollender
one missing - 5 - boxes
came last week -They
are put in the cellar - Sister
Mary forbids their going into the
garrett - Mrs Gannet telephoned
for Sister Mary & me to come
there to dinner - Lydia Cooley Ward
is there --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony returned home from Arma on May 9th after being banished for three weeks due to paint. She received seven boxes of books from Hollender, one missing. Sister Mary forbids the books from going into the garrett. Mrs Gannet invited Susan B. Anthony and Sister Mary to dinner and Lydia Cooley Ward was there.

entries.fullText:
May
Thur
14

At home-painting nearly
done- settling is slow work- but
the house is nice - from top to
bottom - Mrs James Sargent called
and I sold a leather Vol. IV to her -
Sister May gone down town to see
Mrs Van Hoesen
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home, painting and settling in. She sells a book to Mrs. James Sargent and her sister May goes to see Mrs. Van Hoesen in town.

entries.fullText:
- Despatched to the
Hollenbach Press - on account -
for Vol. III - $3,000 - -
Sent Adam's express paid - to Cousin
Hattie Cook County - & told her to tell
her daughter at Bridgeport Ct to
get the book to Mr Henry J. Lewis -
entries.summaryText: Sent payment for Vol. III and instructed Cousin Hattie to have her daughter in Bridgeport deliver the book to Mr. Henry J. Lewis.

entries.fullText:
June
Fri
5

Went to Dr. Sherman
Rickers 10th Anniversary - she
was married to Mr Wentworth Ricker
just 10 years ago today -by Rev
Clarence Barbour - he his wife - and
his mother were present - at the
New Lake home - a beautiful cottage.
Sister May came home at evening
and I remained all night
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends Rickers' 10th anniversary celebration at New Lake and spends the night with her sister May.

entries.fullText: Went home with Mrs Morse- in automobile to Electric Car- & then home on that - at about 7. O clock - - Found Harriet May Mills there - was too tired to talk- -.
entries.summaryText: Went home with Mrs Morse and Harriet May Mills was there.

entries.fullText: sent 17 packages 12, single vol IV- an four full sets a little before seven O clock Miss Shaw came - and after breakfast she & Miss Mills went to Dansville on the Erie - after dinner I went to Dr Requas - and he fitted some under teeth - three on the left-side - and two on the right - and one in the center in front - - they promised will--
entries.summaryText: Sent packages and went to the dentist. Miss Shaw and Miss Mills went to Dansville on the Erie.

entries.fullText:
Sent 47 letters.
8 packages-
Monroe County- Political
equality associations annual
convention at Fairport - 9 miles
east of Rochester. Rev Anna
H. Shaw was with us- took a
sleep in the forenoon - and dinner;
and then at 2:45 we went to Fairport
& there was a good audience in the
Baptist Church. Rev E. E. Knapp the
minister - his wife a fine woman -
stayed only to the P. M. meeting- and then
came home on the 7:[?] train- Miss
Shaw Mrs. of East Hamlim- and
sister Mary came at 11 O clock
Now my teeth- but my gums
were very sore.
entries.summaryText: Attended a political equality convention in Fairport with Rev Anna H. Shaw and Rev E. E. Knapp.

entries.fullText:
Sent 27 letters
Anna Shaw left at 7:20
for Olean- N.Y. and Mrs
for home at Hamlin
My gums were too sore
for anything- so took
them out- and let my
gums heal up- Went to
Dr. Requas- but found him
out- a Dr Willetts from
San Francisco called- she had
a line from Mary Swifer Spery
entries.summaryText: Anna Shaw left for Olean and Susan B. Anthony had to remove her sore gums.

entries.fullText:
Sent 30 Letters
Yes- a $10 gold piece
came from Rhody J. Kenyon
of Centre White Creek -now
on 1 - Eagles [?] - She is always
true to sending - something
entries.summaryText: Received a $10 gold piece from Rhody J. Kenyon of Centre White Creek and sent 30 letters.

entries.fullText:
Sent 48 Letters
and 15 books - all
Vol III
It
entries.summaryText: Sent 48 letters and 15 books of Vol III.

entries.fullText:
Sent 56 letters
sent no book - vol III
Attended the funeral
of Joseph A. Stull - judge
at the Universalist church.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the funeral of Joseph A. Stull, a judge, at the Universalist church and sent 56 letters but no book - vol III.

entries.fullText:
Sent 35 letters
and no books
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent 35 letters and no books.

entries.dateText:
June
Wed
17

Sent 52 letters -
2 full sets of History and
13 vol. IV.
entries.fullText:
Sent 52 letters -
2 full sets of History and
13 vol. IV.
entries.summaryText: Sent 52 letters - 2 full sets of History and 13 vol. IV.

entries.dateText:
June
Thur
18

Sent 19 letters, and one
vol. III, one I II III, and 11
vol. IV.
entries.fullText:
Sent 19 letters, and one
vol. III, one I II III, and 11
vol. IV.
entries.summaryText: Sent 19 letters, and one vol. III, one I II III, and 11 vol. IV.

entries.fullText:
Sent 16 letters and
no books
entries.summaryText: Sent 16 letters and no books

entries.fullText:
Sent 167 letters - 10 packages
of books - 1-2 vols. IV - 3-full
set - 1- full set and vol III and
5 vol IV -
entries.summaryText: Sent 167 letters and multiple packages of books

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & self went
to Church - "The Assets of
Failure" the topic - he counted
a great many good things that came
out of failure to owe the everlasting
principle of right worked for by any one
was always a [g???] - if the end was
reached long after our was
dead - it was good - but
told in one half the words would
have been better far --
entries.summaryText: Attended church with Sister Mary and heard a sermon on the benefits of failure.

entries.fullText:
no letters, no packages
Monday - we have passed
the Rubicon - the longest day -
and now begin to shorten until
we reach the shortest - Dec 21 -
entries.summaryText: No letters or packages received. Reflecting on the summer solstice and the days beginning to shorten.

entries.fullText:
Sent eight letters.
7 packages
Rainy day
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent eight letters and seven packages on a rainy day.

entries.fullText:
Sent 52 letters and
eleven vol. IV.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent 52 letters and eleven volumes on June 24th.

entries.fullText:
Sent 79 letters -
8 packages - 7 vol. IV
of the History - 1 Biography
entries.summaryText: Sent 79 letters and 8 packages including 7 vol. IV of the History and 1 Biography.

entries.fullText:
Sent 6 letters - no
books.
entries.summaryText: Sent 6 letters and no books.

entries.fullText:
Sent 143 letters and
no books.
entries.summaryText: Sent 143 letters and no books.

entries.fullText:
Sent 7 vol. IV and
and 41 letters.
entries.summaryText: Sent 7 vol. IV and 41 letters.

entries.fullText:
Sent 123 letters
and four books
This is Sister Guelma P. A. McLeans
85th birthday - she is two years - or a
year a half older than I. - "Where are they"
all - Gulema and Aaron - Anna Eliza, Thomas King -
and who "where are they" -

Sister Mary and I went to Dr J. E. and
Mrs. Henry Thayer Sanfords 25th Silver
Wedding Anniversary - it was a very hot night
but a pleasant little party - on the eve of
their departure.
entries.summaryText: Sent letters and books, attended a birthday party and a wedding anniversary.

entries.fullText:
Sent 18 Letters and
6 vol IV and one
copy of "the Revolution."
Wm. P. Breckenridge wants
3: for the fourth volume - said
that I presented to his wife in
the older Riggs House days the first
three volumes - said his three daughters
were doing nicely - each one had
a profession --
entries.summaryText: Sent letters and books, talked to Wm. P. Breckenridge about previous volumes and his daughters' professions.

entries.fullText:
Sent 8 letters and
vol IV and 1 full set
History
Mrs. Stone telephoned that
Mr. and Mrs. Holbrook Blinn - of
San Francisco were there - and Mrs
Blinn came and talked she will call
tomorrow A. M.
entries.summaryText: Received a call from Mrs. Blinn of San Francisco who will call again tomorrow.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary is at
Greenfield - Massachusetts - to day -
The house is doubly lonesome
with the stenographer Edna [Hall?]
out - celebrating her 21st
Mrs. Nellie Blinn - of San Francisco -
was here two hours and we were talking
over the suffrage friends in California &
on this side the mountains - she has gotten
her eyes open to the real character of Miss [????] -
I called at Mr. L. L. Stowe's - Mrs.
Blinn's step brother - and stayed to dinner
they all sang. Mrs Stowe playing beautifully
- Found all right when I came home
entries.summaryText: Spent the day with Sister Mary in Greenfield and had a visit from Mrs. Nellie Blinn of San Francisco who is now aware of the true character of Miss [????].

entries.fullText:
Cloudy - this morning -
no word from Sister Mary
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a cloudy morning and not receiving any word from Sister Mary.

entries.fullText:
Sent 18 letters and
2 full sets History. 1 set of
reports and on Vol. IV
and on [?] of hearing speeches to
Mr. Stevenson - at Pittsfield Mass
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about sending letters and sets of history and reports. She also mentions hearing speeches by Mr. Stevenson in Pittsfield, Massachusetts.

entries.fullText:
142 letters mailed
3 Vols IV sent
entries.summaryText: 142 letters mailed and 3 Vols IV sent.

entries.fullText:
a letter from Sister
Mary - They had arrived
Boothbay Harbor, and were
called off with a good night's
sleep at their hotel - then had
[?] on that A.M.
Mr. Gannett came to
tea - had good bread & good butter -
and nice omelette - and black raspberries
and tea - I showed him the
whole house - the clean [?] -
and paper - all through -
Edna Hale worked on the
[?] scrap book all the day -
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary arrived at Boothbay Harbor and had a good night's sleep. Mr. Gannett came for tea and Edna Hale worked on a scrapbook.

entries.fullText:
50 letters mailed
7 vols IV sent
____________
19 of the letters were
autograph letters - I had
kept them waiting for the
History circular - the other
20 - Edna wrote -
A letter from Mrs. Harper
saying she would arrive here
tomorrow, Saturday night at 11 OClock
entries.summaryText: 50 letters were mailed and 7 volumes were sent. Edna wrote 20 letters and there was a letter from Mrs. Harper saying she would arrive the next day at 11 PM.

entries.fullText:
Sent 15 letters
No books
entries.summaryText: Sent 15 letters and no books.

entries.fullText:
Sent 7 packages -
6 Vol IV and one
I & III.
Cold weather nice
rains in the forenoon and
quite a little [?]
entries.summaryText: Sent 7 packages, including 6 Vol IV and one I & III. Cold weather with nice rains in the forenoon and some other event in the afternoon.

entries.fullText:
July
Wed
15

Sent 21 - Letters
Sent 5 Vol IV / Full Set
and one package with 2 Vol IV -
and Vols. I II III
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent letters and books.

entries.fullText:
Sent 4 Vol. IV
and 3 letters
entries.summaryText: Sent 4 Vol. IV and 3 letters

entries.fullText:
Sent 30 [30] letters
and no books
the first thing in the morning
I heard a great noise - I put
on wrapper and went to the front
and it was Dan Jr, his wife Bessie
Hanens- two babies- Eleanor .5. years old
and Dan. Jr. no. 2. and a nurse girl - colored -
- there were here to breakfast - dinner &
supper - I was glad enough to see them
D.J. had sent a telegram last night but
came after I was in bed - & Mrs Harper
wouldn't let them disturb me - I was
glad enough that I had a good night's
rest - Mrs H. left at 11. O clock for [?].-- The whole [fin?] went to bed and were
all found asleep at 5 1/2 O clock - when
I had to waken them - they took the
train at 6.40 - for Boston - they were on
their way to Edgarton - Martha's Vineyard --
entries.summaryText: Received a visit from Dan Jr, his wife Bessie Hanens, two babies, and a nurse girl. They stayed for breakfast, dinner, and supper before leaving for Boston to go to Edgarton - Martha's Vineyard.

entries.fullText:
Rev Anna H. Shaw came at 2.20 -
took dinner with me - and left
on the 5.40 - for Chautauqua - where
she speaks tomorrow Monday - at 2 P.M.
I went to station for her and with
her when she left - She talked very fast -
but I forgot to give her Lucy's E. [?] - &
then never thought of the box of flowers
that Mrs. Stanger sent her - until
Margaret put them on the table Monday
morning - [?] was being too forgetful
for any thing - and we talked too busy --
entries.summaryText: Rev Anna H. Shaw visits Susan B. Anthony and they have dinner together before Shaw leaves for Chautauqua.

entries.fullText:
Sent 12 letters and
4 vol. IV.
Johnathan Staples of Granville
Corners - Washington Co. N. York -
called - he was aunt Sylvia Rogers
Staples - aunt Ruth Rogers [?]
sister's son
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sends letters and books and receives a visit from Johnathan Staples, who is related to her through her aunts Sylvia Rogers Staples and Ruth Rogers.

entries.fullText:
July
Thur
23

Sent 7 letters and
2 vol. IV -
Sister Mary returned home this
noon - She has been gone thru week.
- Mr. Gilbert Mason, Anna, [?],
and her mother here to dinner - Her
mother is a nice looking woman - She took
a great deal of interest in every nook
and corner that her Anna used to
[?] & work in --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent letters and received visitors, including Mr. Gilbert Mason, Anna, and Anna's mother who took an interest in Anna's work.

entries.fullText:
Sent nothing
Mr. L. A. Hines - died this [?],
from first stroke of paralysis
10 years ago - he has been well
enough to ride out - & take comfort
with his family - until two weeks ago
when he became unconscious --
Mrs. Mary Seaman Willis - wife of
Isaac Willis - died - after ten
years at the Dr. Bunells Sanatorium -
Canandaigua - N.Y. - a religious manor -
at 4. this afternoon - her two sons -
Henry & Robert were with - she had been
unconscious for about 9 days - Her father
is at Penn - a [?] on stocks -
financially - - Peace be unto her - She had much
[?] - she was a beautiful woman -
entries.summaryText: Mr. L. A. Hines died from first stroke of paralysis 10 years ago. Mrs. Mary Seaman Willis, wife of Isaac Willis, died after ten years at the Dr. Bunells Sanatorium.

entries.fullText:
Sent nothing
Went to Mrs Sarah Willis and [?] to tea - Sister Mary along -
entries.summaryText: Went to Mrs Sarah Willis and [?] to tea with Sister Mary.

entries.fullText:
Sent two volume
IV and 5 letters

I went in the A.M. down
to Mr. L.A. Hines - saw
their daughter Marnie - Mrs. Johnson
- Baker - there - she lives in Wellesley
- her daughter in College & son pre
paring for College - Jennie Hughes
two boys live in Colorado - & are well -
In the P.M. called at Sara
Willis - Mrs. Willis looked calm
and serene - it is good to see
her at rest after "[?] fitful
dream" - There came a Telegram
at 9 P.M. saying - "Missed the train by
one minute." - Mary Wright Sewall -
- so that is all in.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mr. L.A. Hines and his family, and then visits Sara Willis. She receives a telegram from Mary Wright Sewall.

entries.fullText:
Sent no books,
and three letters

The funeral of Mr. Hines at
10.30 - this A.M. Mr. Gannett
to minister to them - attended the
funeral of Mr. Hines - Mr. G.
spoke, a very little above a
whisper - no one could hear a word
frankly - and then were so many
strangers from different Churches there -
At 2:30 - went to the funeral
of Mary Seaman Willis - Isaac
the husband not there - just their two sons
and relatives -- Mr. Seaman came from
Long Island over 80 - his son with him -
Dr Rishmore came from Plainfield - N.J.
- Mr. Willard officiated - he spoke so as
to be heard - Mary's face was as beautiful as
chiseled marble - she looks so beautiful -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the funerals of Mr. Hines and Mary Seaman Willis.

entries.fullText:
Sent 5 vol IV and
14 letters.

A telegram came last night
from Mrs. Sewall - saying a
friend would come and stay all night -
- so after 11 Oclock - Miss Gertrude
Waldeman came - I new nothing
of it until morning - when I went to
breakfast a beautiful woman was there.
entries.summaryText: Received a telegram from Mrs. Sewall and had an unexpected guest, Miss Gertrude Waldeman.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Sewell - Mrs Swift and
Mrs. Wheeler Pierce of Indianapolis -
all in New York - and going to
sail on the Frederick deGrosse for
Dresden - so Mrs. Sewall has good
company after all.
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Sewell, Mrs. Swift, and Mrs. Wheeler Pierce are in New York and are going to sail to Dresden on the Frederick deGrosse.

entries.fullText:
Sent nothing
worked on Mrs. Stanton's
scrap-book and hunted through
the garret for scrap
After tea - called on Anna
[?] Mason - found her brother
had left yesterday - Thursday A.M.
[?] - I went to call on her
after that call - Anna walked with
me to Chile Avenue - then I walked
to corner of West Avenue - and called on
Dr. Baldwin & mother - had a
nice visit - got home at half
past nine --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony worked on Mrs. Stanton's scrap-book, called on Anna Mason, walked to Chile Avenue, called on Dr. Baldwin and mother.

entries.fullText:
Sent 20 letters and
one Vol. IV
A letter came from Miss Shaw to
Lucy E. this A.M. from Warren Ohio
So Lucy E. learned - he coming here to day -
Mrs. Willis, Hallowell
and Mrs. Patterson called
and made a nice stay.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent letters and a book, received a letter from Miss Shaw, and had visitors Mrs. Willis, Hallowell, and Mrs. Patterson.

entries.fullText:
Lucy E. Anthony came
on the 8.55 train- Lehigh
Valley Train- Black Diamond -
Nephew Frank Mosher went
to station & brot her to the house
entries.summaryText: Lucy E. Anthony arrives by train and is picked up by Frank Mosher.

entries.fullText:
4 packages -
2 full sets -
one Vol III - & IV -
one Vol. IV -
6 letters written by hand
no stenographer here to day -
entries.summaryText: Packages received and letters written by hand, no stenographer available.

entries.fullText:
Start for Lily Dale - Chataqua
County - N.Y. at 11.
Lucy E. - Sister Mary & self
Sister Mary at the last moment
did not go - at Dunkirk Miss
Emily - Mr Howland & Isabel &
Harriet May Mills - and Miss
Slocum - and Charlotte Perkins
Gilman - all going to Lily Dale.
The whole City of Light was busy
with [?] - the houses decorated
- they took me in carriage - [?]
the hand - they had intended to have
the carriage drawn by [?] - but
the rain prevented - it was
a royal [?] - Mrs Pettingill
is just as nice as ever -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony starts a trip to Lily Dale with friends and describes the journey.

entries.fullText:
Miss Shaw came to
breakfast - had a good
audience at the morning
conference - all spoke &
I presided - had a larger
number in the afternoon - Miss
Shaw made a good speech
splendid - and in the evening
they had a ball - it was a
jolly affair -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony presides over a conference and attends a ball in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Gilman spoke this
P.M. - What ails our
Brains - She showed they
are not developed because
from childhood all the way
through life it is "don't"
that is said to us -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Gilman spoke about the development of brains and how people are told "don't" from childhood through life.

entries.fullText:
Miss Shaw spoke again - gave the Fate
of Republics
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw spoke about the fate of republics.

entries.fullText: Charlotte Perkins Gilman spoke on the social organism this P.M. - it was a fine lecture - though many seemed not to follow - a little too deep water for them - I changed sleeping plans from No.1 - at the Leolyn Hotel - to Mrs. Pettengills - and slept the last two night in Mrs. P's very own bed - Miss Mills & Isabel took my rooms - at the hotel - it was next to Isabels fathers -
entries.summaryText: Charlotte Perkins Gilman spoke on the social organism. Susan B. Anthony changed sleeping plans from Leolyn Hotel to Mrs. Pettengills.

entries.fullText: Miss Shaw preached suject - The Heavenly Mission - to fuly 2,000 people - it was a splendid audience - completely filling the Auditorium We called on Mr Skidmore he is all broken down - lost his house - don't want Vol IV - though his wife had the other three volumes - [?] since Wednesday we have had a first class woman to speak every afternoon
entries.summaryText: Miss Shaw preached The Heavenly Mission to a splendid audience. Susan B. Anthony called on Mr. Skidmore who lost his house.

entries.fullText:
Left Lily Dale at 8.52 for
home with Lucy E. Anthony
and arrived at [?].22 P.M. -
Mrs. Howlands & Mrs Miller, Slocum
went to Chautauqua - Mrs Gilman
Charlotte Perkins - (Stetson) with us -
going to Lake Placid - the Adirondacks. -
Young man & his wife - McLaren who played
with Julia Marlowe - very nice
Found that D.R. Anthony Jr had
called in the forenoon - on his
way home - I was very sorry
to miss him -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels with Lucy E. Anthony and meets several people, including Charlotte Perkins, on their way to Lake Placid.

entries.fullText:
Receiving the last payment on Conrads.
Samuel Conrads & wife's mortgage in
Fort Scott - Kansas to day -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives the last payment on Samuel Conrads' mortgage in Fort Scott, Kansas.

entries.fullText:
Sent 4 packages - 1 Full [both words underlined]
set - Leather - and three
Vol. IV. - Cloth -

Sent 12 letters - Had
a girl here to write for us - Lucy
E. and I - went to - Bank
to get satisfaction signed & Notary
Public - Mrs Emma B Sweet - and forgot
to even thank her - to day nothing about
paying her - It was the last pay-
ment of Samuel Conrad - of
Fort Scott - Kansas - I shall
soon get the last -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent packages and letters, went to the bank with Lucy E. and forgot to thank Mrs Emma B Sweet for signing and notarizing a document.

entries.fullText:
This is Lucy Stone's 85 Birth
Day - she having been on
Aug. 12-18,1818 - It was a
nice gathering - at Mr Clifton
Alexanders - at Forest Lawn -
some 150 people there - Mrs
Elizabeth Smith Miller & her son
Gerritt's wife - widow - and Margaret
Stanton Lawrence came up to the
meeting - and came home with us
& spent the night -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended Lucy Stone's 85th birthday celebration at Mr Clifton Alexanders' in Forest Lawn with around 150 people. Mrs Elizabeth Smith Miller, Gerritt's wife, widow, and Margaret Stanton Lawrence also attended and spent the night with Susan B. Anthony.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Miller & daughter
went calling in forenoon
back to dinner - then left - on
the 2.24. train - for home -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Miller & daughter went calling and left for home.

entries.fullText:
Sent 15 letters and
no books.
entries.summaryText: Sent 15 letters and no books.

entries.fullText:
Sent 10 letters and no books.
Niece Lucy E. Anthony left
on the 9.20 Lehigh Valley train this A.M.
I went to the station with her - and then
called at several places - bought a blouse
small figure - wrapped - for a $1. - it
didn't fit - Tried three more
and [?] it up - got the
value in [?].k.ffs -
entries.summaryText: Sent 10 letters and no books. Niece Lucy E. Anthony left on the 9.20 Lehigh Valley train. Went to the station with her and bought a blouse that didn't fit.

entries.fullText:
Nothing sent out -
Emily Howland came this
afternoon - at 2. Oclock -
Niece Margaret McLean Baker
& little Lawrence - 12 years old - came
at 9.10 - -
entries.summaryText: Emily Howland and Margaret McLean Baker visited, along with little Lawrence.

entries.fullText:
Nothing sent out -
Niece Maggie called on
Mary Sackett - she was gone -
then she went to lunch with
Mrs Gould - & then back -
Miss Howland & I called
on Mrs Greenleaf - & then
home - found Niece Maggie back.
She & Lawrence left for the
9.45 train - felt badly that
I couldn't go to station with
her - & ashamed I didn't
think to order a carriage -
entries.summaryText: Niece Maggie visited and went to lunch with Mrs Gould. Miss Howland and I visited Mrs Greenleaf. Maggie and Lawrence left for the train.

entries.fullText:
Miss Howland & sister Mary &
self took a drive out to
Mr. Posts - out Chili avenue - &
then drove to the old farm - the
house is so fixed over that we
would not recognize - but the
old barn & carriage house
are the same as of old -
Then drove back across the river
by South Park - and down East
Ave - called on Dr. Polly - She
was in her dark room - little
wing of north side of house -
then home - and Emily Howland left
on 2.27. train for home - She is a
beautiful spirit - This is brother
Dan's 79th birth day - and nephew
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and companions took a drive to Mr. Posts and the old farm, visited Dr. Polly, and Emily Howland left for home.

entries.fullText:
Sent 3 letters -

[*Dan's 33d birth day - brother
Daniel sent me a telegram
yesterday - with greetings - & I
returned - say must celebrate
next year his 80th birth day*]

Mrs. Wyman - the M.C.
Minister's wife from Hamlin
took dinner with us - she
brough her dauther - Ruthann -
to the Hospital yesterday - she had
run a thorn in her knee - when
berrying - & it as very lame -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent letters, received a telegram from her brother Daniel, and had dinner with Mrs. Wyman and her daughter Ruthann who had injured her knee while berrying.

entries.fullText:
Sent 10 letters and
two vol IV.
Mr Daniels - lives in the old
homestead at - Adams-
entries.summaryText: Sent 10 letters and two vol IV. Mention of Mr Daniels living in the old homestead at Adams.

entries.fullText:
Sent 37 Foreign letters
and 6 in the United States.
No books sent.
entries.summaryText: Sent 37 Foreign letters and 6 in the United States. No books sent.

entries.fullText:
Send 3. Vols IV
and 8 Letters -
Nicolas Shaw & Samuel
Frazier - here married this afternoon
at Rachel Foster Avery's - by Rev Anna
H. Shaw - a host were there - they stood out
in the wood near by to be married --
on the 27th came a letter dated the 25th & $25 -
from brother D.R. - saying he
wanted full set of History. 4 Vols.
and set of the life and work of S.B.A. - 2. Vols.
and all papers and letter of his &
fathers - and all that would
throw light on his forthcoming
project of writing reminiscences -
- Maude is at Marquette Mich -
is still weak - and Sister Anna
is going up to stay with her - our
Louis is coming home - it is too
bad that Maude must suffer so
much -
entries.summaryText: Nicolas Shaw and Samuel Frazier got married at Rachel Foster Avery's. Brother D.R. requested a full set of History and set of the life and work of S.B.A. Maude is still weak and Sister Anna is going up to stay with her. Louis is coming home.

entries.fullText:
The girl working on
Mrs Stanton's scrap book.
I have not heard all of her
speeches - I thought I had most of
them -
Write Miss Pearl Streckey
422 Market St. Emporia - Kansas -
I did not write - I suppose I
thought - I would remember [???]
that - but I have entirely forgotten
Mrs F. Long - of Barry
Illinois - and sister Mrs Metcalf of
Brockport called - Mrs Long is one of the
oldest workers in Ill - was on Library
Board - and got Mrs Stanton and me & others
there to speak & entertained all at her house -
and her house is not mentioned in
the text of the History - Vol.1[?] - but
she paid for it - all the same -
so it is - people who have really done the
work - get left out of History -
entries.summaryText: Miss Pearl Streckey needs to be written to. Mrs F. Long and Mrs Metcalf visited. People who have really done the work get left out of History.

entries.fullText:
Sent 7 letter and
one photograph to White &
Wyckoff Mfg Co. of Holyoke,
[Co.] Mass. No books sent.
entries.summaryText: Sent 7 letter and one photograph to White & Wyckoff Mfg Co. of Holyoke, [Co.] Mass. No books sent.

entries.fullText:
Sent three -
Vols - IV --
Had long call from
Frank Rickenbaugh -
Mrs. Wyman took her little
daughter home -
entries.summaryText: Sent three - Vols - IV -- Had long call from Frank Rickenbaugh - Mrs. Wyman took her little daughter home -

entries.fullText:
Sent 6- letters-
Written by hand-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent 6 letters by hand.

entries.fullText:
No book
Sent 7 letters
[writing?] for articles of
Mrs Stanton for the
draft book -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent 7 letters and worked on writing articles for Mrs. Stanton's draft book.

people: Mrs. Thayer's brother, Dr. Sydney Severance
entries.fullText:
Sent 20 letters
and no books.
May & self went to John
M. Thayers in the evening - Mrs.
Thayer's brother, Dr. Sydney Severance
was there - Dan. Anthony & wife & Gertrude
were there - & the Sanfords -
entries.summaryText: Sent 20 letters and went to John M. Thayers in the evening with May, Mrs. Thayer's brother, Dr. Sydney Severance, Dan. Anthony, Gertrude, and the Sanfords.

entries.fullText:
Sent - 7 - letters -
The sun shines - it is
a pleasant & warm day -
Helen McMillan - called
entries.summaryText: Sent 7 letters and had a pleasant and warm day. Helen McMillan called.

entries.fullText:
I let Ida L. Hall go home - I could give
her anything to do - when Mrs Harper gets
here - there will be enough -
Mrs. Sewall arrived at 7 A.M,
in good time to breakfast with us -
She is looking very well - she says she
is perfectly well - it is great contrast to
the look she had at New Orleans -
Well her report of the Dresden - meeting of
the executives - was that she carried every
[?] - but one - most of Australia
being but one count - its 6 states - as the
United States is but one country - .
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Sewall arrived and reported on the Dresden meeting of the executives.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & I went
to Church - to hear Mr. Gannett
tell about his [sermons?] [?]
on the hills of old Bennington
Vermont - and their wheel ride
through Williamstown & Adams
and sleeping in the hay
bed my father slept on when
a boy -
entries.summaryText: Attended church and heard Mr. Gannett speak about the hills of old Bennington, Vermont.

entries.fullText:
September
Wed
9

Ms Harper came this
night at 9 OClock. She left
Winnifred in Buffalo Station
to take train for Grand Rapids
Mich
entries.summaryText: Ms Harper came to visit and left Winnifred at Buffalo Station to take a train to Grand Rapids, Mich.

entries.fullText:
Hattie Stanton Blatch
came at 6 P.M. - Had good
talk - Mrs Harper slept in back
bedroom - & Hattie in front room -
entries.summaryText: Hattie Stanton Blatch came to visit and had a good talk with Susan B. Anthony.

entries.fullText:
Hattie took carriage and
rode Mrs Rohns - to get a
girl - & then we rode [down] up
East avenue - everything
looked green & beautiful -
then back to dinner - & she
took the 2.27 train for
Geneva -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Hattie rode around East avenue and enjoyed the scenery before Hattie left on the train for Geneva.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Harper Mary and self
went to church - Mrs
Gannett back - the sermon
was a century of Liberal
Religion - its influence [?]
creed even the Roman Catholic
very much modified - it was
splendid -

Kate Gleason & her
father William Gleason - took
Mrs. Harper and me to the South
Park Club house to dinner - &
then drove through the park
across to East Avenue & found
a pleasant - but hot time
entries.summaryText: Attended church with Mrs. Harper and Mrs. Gannett, heard a sermon on Liberal Religion. Had dinner with Kate Gleason and her father at South Park Club house and drove through the park to East Avenue.

entries.fullText: Sent one Vol IV
entries.summaryText: Sent one Vol IV

entries.fullText:
September
Tues
15

The Sherwood Political
Equality Club - meets - no
meeting held -
entries.summaryText: The Sherwood Political Equality Club did not hold a meeting.

entries.fullText: [No entry for this date]
entries.summaryText: No entry written on September 17, 1903

entries.fullText:
Sent eight letters
and no books.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote on September 18, 1903 that she sent eight letters and no books.

entries.fullText:
September
Mon
21

Sent 21 books
and 17 letters -
17 books - Vol IV - went to
foreign countries
entries.summaryText: Sent 21 books and 17 letters, including 17 books from Vol IV to foreign countries.

entries.fullText: Sent 8 letters
entries.summaryText: Sent 8 letters

entries.fullText:
Sent 49 letters - to
and no books
Contributors of History about
destroying the original copies -
entries.summaryText: Sent 49 letters - to and no books Contributors of History about destroying the original copies -

entries.fullText:
Sent [11] 12 letters -
four foreign; and
one vol IV - History.
To Taylor and Baker -
_____________________
Got word from E.J. Chapin
that he was about selling the old
Brown Place. Told him he might
[?] five dollar - if he chose - $185 -,
- this follows on Dempsey's paying
off on his lot -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent 12 letters and a book to Taylor and Baker. She received word that E.J. Chapin was selling the old Brown Place and discussed payment with him.

entries.fullText:
No letters sent -
no books - but yesterday
one to Baker and John

Letter from dear
Rachel Foster - Avery -
saying she was going to
Ithica- & would come home on
Monday -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not send any letters or books. She received a letter from Rachel Foster-Avery who was going to Ithica and planned to come home on Monday.

entries.fullText:
September
Sun
27

September
Mon
28
Sent 10 letters
and three vol II -
one Vol IV to Strassburg,
Germany. Two foreign letters -
one to Strassburg and one to Christiana
Norway.
entries.summaryText: Sent 10 letters and three vol II - one Vol IV to Strassburg, Germany. Two foreign letters - one to Strassburg and one to Christiana Norway.

entries.fullText:
Sent one letter -
birthday letter to Miss
Nora Stanton Blatch, Ithaca.
N.Y. tomorrow - Sept 30th -
is the day - 1883. - Mrs. Stanton
waited the event - and six weeks
after - and we sailed for the
United States Nov. 17 1883 -
Mrs. Foster Avery took me down town
and purchased me cloth for three
dresses - travelling - dark gray - morning dark
red - evening light gray stripe -- it
was too much - I had calculated to
wear what I had until next spring
and then get some new ones -
entries.summaryText: Sent a birthday letter to Miss Nora Stanton Blatch in Ithaca, NY and went shopping for dresses with Mrs. Foster Avery.

entries.fullText:
Twenty-one letters
sent - Twenty to the
Annual State Suffrage
Conventions asking them to
celebrate Mrs. Stanton's birthday and
the tenth year of Suffrage in
Colorado, and purchase the History
of Woman Suffrage - to get - items
about Mrs. Stanton
Rachel left on the Black
Diamond train at 11:40 A.M.
and will get home about 10:20 --
entries.summaryText: Sent letters to State Suffrage Conventions and Rachel left on a train.

entries.fullText:
sent one vol. IV
to Earlville
wrote dear Rachel - and sent her
[p??es] of evening and Sunday dress-
Rained all day - went in A.M.
to see Mrs. Tuttam about making dresses -
entries.summaryText: Sent a book to Earlville and wrote to Rachel. Went to see Mrs. Tuttam about making dresses.

entries.fullText:
sent sent eight state letters.
May Wright Sewall sent
me $250 - Just as much
remains due - with the interest -
- It is a hard struggle for
me to pay up - her school
is a big drag - her work is
very hard and constant --
entries.summaryText: Sent eight state letters. Received $250 from May Wright Sewall, but still has more to pay. May's work is hard and constant.

entries.fullText:
Sent 21 State letters,
no books.
entries.summaryText: Sent 21 State letters, no books.

entries.fullText:
Sent 75 letters to libraries
asking them to buy vol IV
of the History: This is the
second time the circular has
been sent to them. Libraries
sent to were marked with star #
on the list.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent 75 letters to libraries asking them to buy vol IV of the History.

entries.fullText:
Sent 7 letters.
2 vol III - 1 vol IV -
and 2 vols I II III -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent 7 letters regarding the purchase of various volumes of a book series.

entries.fullText:
Sent 21 letters
and no books.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent 21 letters and no books on October 7, 1903.

entries.fullText:
vol I. II. III - Miss F. L. Ransom
= I. II. III - D. M . Richards
- I. II - M. Clurg. Penn Liby -
10. Letters -
Political Equals Club -
meets at "Warner Castle".
entries.summaryText: On October 8, 1903, Susan B. Anthony wrote about exchanging books with Miss F. L. Ransom and D. M. Richards, receiving books from M. Clurg at Penn Liby, writing 10 letters, and attending a meeting of the Political Equals Club at Warner Castle.

entries.fullText:
Sent 9 letters
1 vol IV of History.
To Kansas State University - at Lawrence -
Just a year to day since Anna
E. Dann married Gilbert J Mason - I
[????ted] them - Mother Mason & her sister from
Lima - and Annas sister Charlotte & Mrs Lela
Heath - to a six oclock dinner - had roast
lamb - potatoes fresh & sweet & Lima beans - tomatoes
and pickles - tea & cake & ice cream - Gilbert sent
out [?] - & Anna brou't Nasturteon - all very
nice - they went home at 9 Oclock --
so the wedding anniversary is passed - and
they are as happy to all appearances as at first --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent 9 letters and a volume of history to Kansas State University. She reflects on the one year anniversary of Anna E. Dann's marriage to Gilbert J Mason and describes the dinner she had with them and other family members.

entries.fullText:
No letters
2 Vol. IV -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not send any letters and received volume 2 of IV.

entries.fullText:
October
Sun
11

Sent 14 letters and
2 Full sets of cloth -
1 vol. IV
College women's Club - meets at
Miss C. Wetmores this P.M. - 3 Oclock.
84. South Fitzhugh street -
entries.summaryText: Sent letters and sets of cloth. Attended College women's Club meeting at Miss C. Wetmores.

entries.fullText:
Sent 6 letters -
1 vol. IV
entries.summaryText: Sent 6 letters and 1 volume IV.

entries.fullText:
Sent 18 letters -
3 vol. IV - one by
mail. to Gady Somerset.
England.
entries.summaryText: Sent 18 letters and 3 volume IV, one of which was sent by mail to Gady Somerset in England.

entries.fullText:
Sent 2 letters
and no books
entries.summaryText: Sent 2 letters and no books

entries.fullText:
Sent 13 letters
and no books
Sent large box of old tracts
pamphlets etc. to University
Library at Syracuse
entries.summaryText: Sent 13 letters and a box of old tracts and pamphlets to University Library at Syracuse

entries.fullText:
Sent 25 letters to Brooklyn libraries
and six packages of
History
entries.summaryText: Sent letters and packages to Brooklyn libraries.

entries.fullText:
Sent 9 letters
Sent 6 vol. IV of
History, 1 full set.
1 vol. III [and] 1 vol. I.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent 9 letters and 6 volumes of History, including a full set, one volume III and one volume I.

entries.fullText:
Sent 7 letters.
3 full sets of History
and 1 vol. IV.
entries.summaryText: Sent 7 letters and received 3 full sets of History and 1 vol. IV.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. May Wood Swift (J.F.)
of San Francisco - arrived at 5:20 -
- She will spend the week - glad
to have her - though we are
without a girl --
entries.summaryText: Mrs. May Wood Swift (J.F.) arrived from San Francisco and will spend the week.

entries.fullText:
1 Vol I History sent.
" " II
no letters.
entries.summaryText: Sent Volume I of History and no letters received.

entries.fullText:
Sent 13 letters.
4 sets of Life and Work.
1 full set of History.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent 13 letters, 4 sets of Life and Work, and 1 full set of History on October 29, 1903.

entries.fullText:
Sent 9 letters
and 1 full set History.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent 9 letters and 1 full set of History on October 30, 1903.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Swift left for Indianapolis
on the 9.20. train - after a good
visit - with Sister Mary closing
the House no girl - a woman to
wash and iron - and left -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Swift leaves for Indianapolis after a good visit with Sister Mary, closing the house and leaving no girl, only a woman to wash and iron.

entries.fullText: Sent 15 letters,
entries.summaryText: Sent 15 letters.

entries.fullText:
November
Mon
16

November
Tues
17
Sent 20 letter, E L H,
entries.summaryText: Sent 20 letter to E L H

entries.fullText:
Wrote twenty
letters.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote twenty letters on November 18, 1903.
Susan B. Anthony wrote an entry on November 19, 1903.

entries.fullText:
No [??.] Public School - wants
S.B.A from 20th_1902 - Mrs.
Mary Fish Wilson - 142. [?] st =
Mrs. Abby Sanford Lampert 234. Rey -
Reynolds street - ladies who called
Sister Mary went instead of
me - I had been in a set-back
for a few days --
entries.summaryText: S.B.A was requested at a public school, but was unable to attend due to illness. Several ladies called, but Sister Mary went instead.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Harper, sister Mary
and self went to Mrs. Greenleaf's to
Thanksgiving dinner - first went to
the Church & Mr. Saxe, Mr. Paddington
of the Universalist - Mr. Landsberg of the
Jewishists and Mr. Gannet of the
Unitarian church conducted the
services - came home before lunch -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her companions attended Thanksgiving dinner at Mrs. Greenleaf's and went to church before lunch.

entries.fullText:
Just about 6 oclock - after
a good days work. -- I remember
of feeling stuffed in the afternoon -
but felt I would work on - as long as
I could see - - then went to kitchen
and registered the books that were sent
out in the P.M. - then took the paper
and sat down under the gas - got in
front parlor - My head began to turn
round - I felt faint - and hollered to
sister Mary - she Mrs Harper & their girl -
Carrie were in the kitchen - at last
they heard & came - and I was on the floor -
they worked - rubbing - with camphor - then Dr
Becker came at last - and I was on the sofa -
- the cause was probably eating too much the day
before - after vomiting & purging. - I was pretty
weak - all work like Trojans --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony worked on registering books and reading the paper until she felt faint and collapsed. She was attended to by her companions and Dr. Becker, and the cause was likely overeating the day before.

entries.fullText:
- Well - I have to pay for
over eating - getting cold - or
going to bed cold - overworking - &
whatever else was the cause of my
fainting last night - -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about fainting and possible causes.

entries.fullText:
All work is responded
Mrs Catt gave the Lyceum Lecture -
[?] good - had fine audience
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Mrs. Catt giving a lecture with a good audience.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Harper getting ready
to leave - Mrs Catt called
and spent a half hour - on
her way to [?] train - It was too
bad that hers should be the lecture
I should miss +
entries.summaryText: Mrs Harper is leaving and Mrs Catt visited for half an hour.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Harper busy about
her clothes -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Harper is busy with her clothes.

entries.fullText:
Our Mother's 110th birthday -

Our father's will be Jan 27, 1904 - so mother
was nearly two months older than Father -

We were going to invite Mrs
Hallowell. Moshers' - L P. Smith &
Kate Gleason & her father William
Gleason - but decided it not
best - for I had not sufficently
recovered - But our habit used
to be to have our Thanksgiving turkey
on Dec. 2. - so lovely as we had our
mother with us - which was till [188?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her mother's 110th birthday and her father's upcoming birthday. She mentions people she was going to invite but decided against it due to her own health.

entries.fullText:
Lyman Ward - Principal of
Southern Industrial Institute - for White
Youth - at Camp Hill - Alabama -
will speak in R. some day in the
two first weeks in December - and I
have promised to sit on platform - but
told them he must not announce
me for a speech - that I could not
trust myself for that --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony mentions Lyman Ward, the Principal of Southern Industrial Institute, who will be speaking in R. in December. She has promised to sit on the platform but does not want to be announced for a speech.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Harper left at
11. A. M. for her sisters - Mrs
Hughes - Mayvill - Chau. Co - N. Y.
We felt lonely enough -
entries.summaryText: Mrs Harper left for her sister's house in Mayvill, Chau. Co, N. Y.

entries.fullText:
Did not go to church
Mary Jones of Toledo O
spoke -
entries.summaryText: Missed church, spoke with Mary Jones from Toledo, OH.

entries.fullText:
2 Full sets History, one
leather and one cloth; 2
of vol. IV, cloth; 2 of vol IV
in leather.
Wrote ten letters
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about purchasing history books and writing ten letters on December 10, 1903.
Susan B. Anthony did not write an entry on December 11, 1903.

entries.fullText: Wrote twelve letters.
entries.summaryText: Wrote twelve letters.

entries.fullText: Caroline Bartlett Crane lectured - on mind your own business - small audience - dreadfully cold - Mr Gannett introduced her - Lyceum - not nearly full - I felt I should not venture out -
entries.summaryText: Caroline Bartlett Crane lectured on 'mind your own business' to a small audience at the Lyceum, introduced by Mr Gannett. Susan B. Anthony did not attend due to the cold weather and low attendance.

entries.fullText:
Very cold indeed - coldest of the
season -
Sent Julia B. Nelson - red [?] -
[?] - my cut [underlined] - by mail - [mail underlined]
She promises to send it right back
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the cold weather and sending something to Julia B. Nelson.

entries.fullText:
Wrote twenty-two
letters
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about writing 22 letters.

entries.fullText:
Sent Full set History
in leather; 1 copy report
Council, 1891.
Wrote eighteen letters.
entries.summaryText: Sent Full set History in leather; 1 copy report Council, 1891. Wrote eighteen letters.

entries.fullText: Wrote thirty-six letters.
entries.summaryText: Wrote thirty-six letters.

entries.fullText: Wrote eleven letters.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote eleven letters on December 18, 1903.

entries.fullText:
Wrote twelve letters.
Sent Full set leather; vol. IV,
Leather; 7 vols. of vol. IV; 2
sets of Life [and] work.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote twelve letters on December 19, 1903 and sent some books.

entries.fullText:
Did not go to Church
Mr Winship of
Boston spoke to night.
He and Mr Learing came
to call or me
entries.summaryText: Miss Anthony did not go to church. Mr. Winship of Boston spoke tonight and he and Mr. Learing came to call on her.
Miss Anthony received twenty-two letters today and received a 2-volume set of 'Life & Work' in cloth binding.
Susan B. Anthony wrote 22 letters and made bookkeeping entries for the sale of various volumes and sets of books.

entries.fullText:
Twenty-one letters;
Vol. IV, cloth, Photogravure
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote 21 letters and made a bookkeeping entry for the sale of a volume of cloth with photogravure.

entries.fullText: Sent Vol. IV, Cloth.
entries.summaryText: Sent Vol. IV, Cloth.

entries.fullText: Christmas Day - go to Rev [????] C. + Mary Lewis Gannett to dinner they sent carriage for sister May + self -
entries.summaryText: Went to dinner at Rev [????] C. and Mary Lewis Gannett's house for Christmas, they sent a carriage for May and Susan.

entries.fullText:
Wrote six letters.
Harriet Stanton Blatch came
at 5.30 -
entries.summaryText: Wrote six letters. Harriet Stanton Blatch came.

entries.fullText:
A strong cold
night so did not go to
hear Hattie speak.
entries.summaryText: A strong cold night so did not go to hear Hattie speak.

entries.fullText:
Wrote eleven letters.
Sent 3 vol. IV, cloth; 1 Set
History in Leather; 2 Sets
of Life.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote eleven letters and sent various books and sets.

entries.fullText:
Sent Life + work; 1 Picture
of Mrs. Stanton and one
of Miss Anthony to Anna
S. Ely.
Wrote eighteen letters.
Full of Life + work.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sent books and a picture to Anna S. Ely and wrote eighteen letters about her life and work.

entries.fullText: Sent Mrs. Harriet Stanton Blatch, box of her mother's letters to S.B.A.
entries.summaryText: Sent a box of letters to Mrs. Harriet Stanton Blatch.

entries.fullText: Wrote sixteen letters. Brother Aaron - Sister Guelma's husband would have been 9 this day.
entries.summaryText: Wrote sixteen letters and remembered Guelma's husband's birthday.

entries.dateText:
Rev Anna Garlin Spencer
59 West 44th Street - The Algonquin
New York
entries.fullText:
Rev Anna Garlin Spencer
59 West 44th Street - The Algonquin
New York
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about meeting Rev Anna Garlin Spencer at The Algonquin in New York.

entries.dateText:
Dr. Sarah M. Siewers
747 West 6th st
Cincinnati - Ohio
entries.fullText:
Dr. Sarah M. Siewers
747 West 6th st
Cincinnati - Ohio
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about visiting Dr. Sarah M. Siewers in Cincinnati, Ohio.

entries.fullText: The house today killed the woman's suffrage bill by a vote of 41 to 24. This effectively disposes of the measure at this session.
entries.summaryText: Women's suffrage bill is killed in Montana.
